docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama rang in 2014 by declaring a "year of action," vowing to strengthen the nation by focusing on fairness, competitiveness and the power of American diplomacy. Since Congress seemed unwilling to help, the president said he'd act alone.

docs.lead_paragraph: Justices Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg have both acknowledged shifting positions in recent cases, and found an ally from the past.
docs.snippet: Justices Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg have both acknowledged shifting positions in recent cases, and found an ally from the past....
docs.abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column explores how Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia admitted mistake in his approach to whether court should hear appeals; highlights admission as model for a judge grappling with inconsistent application of law; notes historical examples of Supreme Court justices straying from ideal of consistency.

headline.print_headline: Supreme Court Justices Admit Inconsistency, and Embrace It
headline.main: Supreme Court Justices Admit Inconsistency, and Embrace It

docs.lead_paragraph: When Republicans take full control of Congress on Jan. 6, they will face decisions on major changes at the Congressional Budget Office, including possibly naming a new head and changing the rules used to assess the cost of legislation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Like Bush’s, his last two years might be the best ones.

byline.original: By IAN AYRES and JOHN FABIAN WITT

docs.snippet: Like Bush’s, his last two years might be the best ones....
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Profs Ian Ayres and John Fabian Witt submits that Pres Obama may be least lame duck president in history, having taken dramatic action on immigration, climate change and relations with Cuba in his first month and a half as lame duck; holds that political changes during George W Bush and Obama presidencies have given them unprecedented capacity for unilateral executive authority during last two years of term; urges Obama to continue taking decisive and progressive action while he has opportunity to do so.

docs.lead_paragraph: The precise mix of Republican candidates who enter the 2016 presidential race or decide to stay out of it will greatly affect the party's choice of nominee.

byline.original: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

docs.snippet: The precise mix of Republican candidates who enter the 2016 presidential race or decide to stay out of it will greatly affect the party's choice of nominee....

docs.lead_paragraph: JENSEN--Camille McLean Anderson. Died on December 18 of natural causes at her residence in Darien, Connecticut. She was 95. Camille was born on December 14, 1919, in Holly Springs, Mississippi, the daughter of Percy Harmon and Camille McLean Anderson. She attended Miss Hutchison's School in Memphis and graduated from Mary Baldwin College in Staunton, Virginia, in 1941. In 1942 she was named Maid of Cotton at the Memphis Cotton Carnival by the National Cotton Council. She married Frode Jensen, a physician, in 1948 and settled in Denver, Colorado. In 1950 they moved to Riverdale, New York, where she participated in the Parent Teachers Association at the Riverdale Country School, was a founding member of the Board of the Wave Hill Association, served on the board of the Girl Scouts Association of Greater New York, was a founder of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church Nursery School, and was a member of the board of governors of the Riverdale Yacht Club. On weekends she and Frode enjoyed their country home at the Gipsy Trail Club in Carmel, New York. After her husband's death in 1973, Camille enjoyed a successful career as a realtor in Riverdale with Robert E. Hill, Inc. In 1987, she retired and moved to New Canaan, Connecticut, where she lived for 25 years. Camille was predeceased by her husband, Frode, and is survived by her three children; her son, Frode (Skip) and his wife, Kitty, of Park City, Utah, her daughter Camille, of Manhattan, and her son, Peter, of Phoenixville, Pennsylvania. She is also survived by her five grandchildren: Christian McLean, Catherine Spotswood Hall, and Henry Carter Jensen; and Matthew St. John and Alexander Jensen Douglas. Funeral arrangements are being handled by Edward Lawrence Funeral Home in Darien, CT. Funeral services will be private. Camille will be interred in the Hamilton College Cemetery. A memorial service next spring is planned in Clinton, NY. Contributions in Camille's memory can be made to the Frode and Camille Jensen Scholarship Fund at Hamilton College, 198 College Hill Road, Clinton, NY 13323.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren, who has denied plans to run for president, may challenge Hillary Rodham Clinton, in her own way, to focus on income inequality on the trail.
docs.snippet: Senator Elizabeth Warren, who has denied plans to run for president, may challenge Hillary Rodham Clinton, in her own way, to focus on income inequality on the trail....
docs.abstract: Political Memo; Several liberal groups are trying to propel first-time Sen Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, into 2016 presidential race as primary challenger to Hillary Clinton; Warren repeatedly says she will not run but may use her populism to challenge Clinton on income inequality.

headline.main: Role for Warren: To Push, if Not Supplant, Clinton
headline.print_headline: Role for Warren: To Push, if Not Supplant, Clinton
